title: Running Injuries and Foot Health
content: Research of biomechanics and clinical work with running injuries has shaped views on maintaining body alignment and foot health. There is an argument for the role of modern footwear in running-related injuries and how minimalist footwear helps resolve the subsequent biomechanical issues.

title: Evolution of the Human Foot and Running
content: The evolution of the human foot and the transition from walking to running has been studied. The evolution of shoes and its impact on running injuries has also been explored.

title: Overview of Running Injuries
content: Running injuries can be caused by various factors. Cushioned running shoes, heel striking and impact forces can contribute to these injuries. Shin splints and knee stress through rate of loading are common issues.

title: Importance of Exercise
content: Exercise is critically important for maintaining health and preventing injuries. Impact forces and injury potential are factors to consider during exercise.

title: Minimalist Shoes and Orthotics
content: Minimalist shoes can help resolve biomechanical issues caused by modern footwear. Transitioning people out of orthotics and into minimalist shoes can be beneficial. Foot muscle volume, minimalist shoes, and orthotics are interconnected.

title: Foot Strength in Podiatry
content: The importance of foot strength is recognized in podiatry. Minimalist shoes can be used across the lifespan—from children to adults.

title: Knee Injury Factors
content: Knee valgus and other factors can contribute to knee injury. IT band syndrome is a common issue.

title: Retraining a Runner's Gait
content: Retraining a runner's gait can help prevent injuries and improve performance. The transition to minimalist shoes can decrease injury and improve performance.

title: Proper Movement Patterns
content: Proper movement patterns are important for health and injury prevention. The modern environment can negatively influence these patterns.

content: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent.

title: Orthotics and Biomechanics
content: How the use of orthotics has changed. Early in the career, orthotics were prescribed as a physical therapist. The permanent nature of orthotics is the opposite of this approach. Despite the common thinking that we should be prescribing a shoe type based on an individual’s need for support, a study found that there was no difference in injury rate.

title: Evolution of the Human Foot
content: Anatomical changes from walking man (Australopithecus) to running man (Homo erectus). Joint surfaces became larger to bear greater forces. The longitudinal and medial longitudinal arches developed. The achilles tendon became longer for greater energy storage. The foot has 26 bones, 33 articulations, and six degrees of freedom, resulting in a complex structure. It has four layers of arch muscle comprised of 10 muscles. This complexity allows for a stable base of support while being able to adapt to uneven terrain and absorb shock.

title: Evolution of Shoes and Running Injuries
content: The earliest known shoes date back to 10,000 years ago. They were made with sage brush bark and were basically a flat surface with a strap, similar to Huarache sandals. The primary purpose was to protect the bottom of the foot. Prior to the 1960s, running footwear was similar to what is sold as minimalist shoes today. As running became a popular activity for the general population, people were getting injured. Achilles tendonitis was common — the general population were used to walking around in shoes with a slightly raised heel.

title: Modern Running Shoes and Injuries
content: The existing running shoes were flat. New running shoes were created with a heel lift and cushioning in an attempt to counteract the injuries. 'Motion control' shoes have a very stiff heel counter and stiffer material in the mid sole. They may also have additional plastic reinforcement, all to prevent the foot from rolling in. 'Cushioning' shoes are for people with a high arch and little foot movement. Running injuries did not appear in the research literature, or at least not nearly as much, until approximately when these specialized shoes appeared.

title: Overview of Running Injuries
content: Running injuries are most commonly from the knee down, but can go all the way up to the neck. The reason why most injuries occur from the knee down is because this is where most shock absorption occurs. Landing incurs a force that is 2.5 to 3 times body weight. At the knee, this force can be 7 times body weight.

title: Cushioned Running Shoes, Heel Striking and Impact Forces
content: Studies have shown that people create greater landing force in the HOKA shoe. The increased cushioning gives a false sense of security that encourages a harder landing. A study has shown that the heel has a relatively low pain threshold that doesn’t extend far beyond the level of force generated during walking—suggesting that we have evolved to be forefoot strikers. Other studies have shown that it is footwear that encouraged many of us to become heel strikers.

title: Shin Splints
content: One of the most common injuries that runners have when they first start running is an 'overuse' injury called shin splints. Shin splints manifest as pain in the front of the lower leg. The primary muscle where this occurs, the tibialis anterior, is much smaller than the muscles in the back of the lower leg. The tibialis anterior concentrically lifts the forefoot towards the knee and eccentrically controls the lowering of the forefoot towards the ground. Because of the smaller size, the tibialis anterior is more prone to the fatigue and overuse that can result in shin splints.

title: Heel Strike Patterns and Knee Stress
content: A forefoot strike allows for the calf and the motion of the foot to absorb some of the impact force and also allows the transition of force from the foot to the knee to occur gradually. With a heel strike, more of the impact force goes directly to the knee, and the force is transferred more rapidly. Studies have shown higher rates of force transfer to be associated with running injuries.

title: The Critical Importance of Exercise
content: The documentary follows a high school boot camp-style fitness program. All of the kids in this program ended fit and looking like they were in the military. Basic movement skill fosters proper running mechanics and that the lack of such skill is the reason why so many people today have improper running mechanics. But you do need to be fit to run because being fit implies development of the motor control needed to run properly.

title: Impact Forces and Injury Potential
content: Based on work with runners on a treadmill equipped with a force plate, heel striking leads to a more rapid rate of vertical force development. Forefoot striking in minimalist shoes decreases the rate of force development.

title: Shoe Cushioning and Impact Forces
content: Forefoot striking in cushioned shoes has unwanted effects. It promotes landing with more plantar flexion (forefoot more pointed towards ground), which exposes the Achilles tendon to greater stress. It also promotes landing on the outside of the foot, which causes an increase in lateral forces. This tends to result in problems in both the Achilles and peroneal tendons.

title: Overview of Minimalist Shoes
content: Three brands of minimalist shoes that you can roll up and put in your pocket are Vivobarefoot, Xero, and Inov-8. There are now a number of 'partial' minimalist shoes, which tend to have cushioning, a heel-to-toe drop, and sometimes arch support. A major problem with these shoes is that they still encourage people to heel strike, but with less cushion. In one study, partial minimal shoes were associated with twice as much injuries as fully minimalist shoes.

title: Transitioning to Minimalist Shoes and a Forefoot Strike
content: It’s a one to three month process, depending on age. Focus spans to include foot, hip, and knee function. Activities like hopping, lunging, and jumping rope are included to develop dynamic movement skill. Only after basic movement function has been developed does treadmill training start. Someone should be able to handle a 30-minute brisk walk with forefoot strike and minimalist shoes before starting on a treadmill. Otherwise, consequences include plantar fasciitis and metatarsal stress fracture.

title: Foot Muscle Volume, Minimalist Shoes, and Orthotics
content: A study showing that cross sectional volume of foot muscles is larger in people who run with minimalist shoes. Another study has shown that people who start wearing orthotics experience a decrease in foot muscle volume.

title: The Recognition of the Importance of Foot Strength in Podiatry
content: Recently published physical therapy guidelines for plantar fasciitis include orthotics and other approaches, but neglect to include strengthening. In contrast, guidelines for any other part of the body do include strengthening. Despite this, there is an increasing interest in using exercise and movement training instead of orthotics.

title: Minimalist Shoes Across the Lifespan
content: Minimalist shoes are important for kids so that their feet develop properly. Since we lose muscle power with age, and in the feet and lower extremities first, transitioning to minimalist shoes is important for adults.

title: Why Learning to Forefoot Strike on Soft Surfaces is Not the Best Approach
content: Running barefoot has the benefit of maximizing sensory input from ground contact. Running on grass barefoot is not a good idea because you may not see things that will injure your foot. Soft surfaces in general will encourage more stiffness throughout the body. In contrast, harder surfaces will encourage a softer landing.

title: Knee Valgus and Factors Related to Knee Injury
content: Injuries are multifactorial. Poor movement pattern is not always the cause. While someone with poor movement will likely be injured more quickly, someone with good movement still has increased injury risk if their dose of movement is too high. Poor movement can manifest as injury in different ways – for example, knee valgus might cause knee pain, but it may instead cause hip pain.

title: IT Band Syndrome
content: The iliotibial band (or IT band for short) connects the tensor fasciae latae to the lateral (outside) part of the tibia at the knee. Inward rotation of the tibia was also found in these studies, which is associated with pronation (rolling in) of the foot, also stretches the IT band. Based on the above mechanisms, IT band syndrome can originate from the hip or the foot.

title: Physics and Ground Reaction Forces
content: Ground reaction forces are an example of Newton’s third law of physics (for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction). For example, when you push against the ground, because of the massive size of earth, the ground will not move. The reaction is therefore translated into pushing yourself away from the ground rather than pushing the ground away.

title: Joint Forces and Mechanics
content: As these reaction forces are transferred through joints, they compress the joint in the process, which is how the force within the joint ends up being greater than the original amount of force being applied because of the internal moment arm in the joint and because of other stabilizing muscles contracting across the other side of the joint.

title: Gait Retraining
content: Mechanics is something that’s very modifiable. Gait can be reprogrammed. Gait retraining requires a lot of practice. It is not easy to retrain a movement pattern that has been engrained for decades. Feedback is helpful, but must eventually be faded out. The process involves an average of two months spent working on gait, four weeks of gait training on the treadmill, and then 10 weeks of supervised incremental increases in running.

title: Prevention and Health Insurance
content: The logical approach would be a proactive retraining of gait to prevent injury. However, insurance only covers gait retraining after injury. Because of this, 100% of the gait retraining is with people who have already been injured. Treating type 2 diabetes costs $7,000 to $12,000 per year compared to spending about $500 per year to prevent someone from ever getting the disease.

title: Evidence of Gait Retraining Effectiveness
content: One study involving 320 novice runners found that half of the runners were trained on a treadmill to soften their impact. A year later, there was a 62% decrease in injuries. Similarly, a retrospective study found that forefoot strikers had half of the chronic injuries as heel strikers.

title: Transition to Minimalist Shoes
content: A physician resolved his own foot problems by running barefoot and in minimalist shoes. He gradually started recommending it to members of the community’s track team who had season-ending injuries and weren’t responding to standard of care. Eventually, 80% of the community was wearing minimalist shoes, and referrals to podiatrists decreased as use of minimalist shoes increased.

title: Proper Movement Patterns and Modern Environment
content: Frequent sitting and wearing of shoes present a major challenge for maintaining proper movement in today’s society. Gym class in schools should be every day and should involve more demanding movement including calisthenics. By the time kids are 12 to 17 years old, about 31% of them have at least one chronic condition. Sport specificity presents similar problems and kids should be encouraged to play multiple sports.
